mentions.context: Interproscan v5.13-52.0

Contigs were then displayed with Blobtools v1.1.1 73 using taxon-annotated-GC-coverage plots.
Then, featureCounts program from the Subread package 86 was used to determine fragment counts per genes using default parameters.

Protein sequences were first aligned with MAFFT v7.017 75 and the maximum-likelihood phylogeny was performed with PhyML 76 using the JTT + G + F substitution model for OR and using HKY80 substitution model for P450 and odv-e66 genes.
The functional annotation was performed using blastp from BLAST + v2.5.0 68 to compare the C. congregata proteins to the NCBI nonredundant database (from the 29/06/2014).
Gaps were filled using GapCloser module from the SOAPdenovo assembler 59 .
The functional annotation was performed using blastp from BLAST + v2.5.0 68 to compare the C. congregata proteins to the NCBI nonredundant database (from the 29/06/2014).
The C. congregata genome was generated by de novo assembly of 454 reads using GS De Novo Assembler from the Newbler software package v2.8 57 .

The automated annotation of the five other Cotesia species was performed using MAKER 67 using the same features as for the annotation of C. congregata but also including the output automated annotation of C. congregata.
The automated gene prediction and annotation of C. congregata genome was done using Gmove (https://github.com/institut-degenomique/Gmove)
Orthologous genes from the six Cotesia species were aligned as described before and codeml (implemented in PAML v4.8) was used to estimate the M0 dN/dS (free ratio model).

The different synteny analyses were performed on the orthologous genes identified by OrthoFinder v1.14 74 and by reciprocal blastp from BLAST + v2.2.28 on the annotated proteins (e-value below 10e -20 ).
Sequencing coverage was deduced after mapping Illumina paired reads to the assembly with Bowtie2 v2.3.4.2 61 .
The Hi-C read library was processed and mapped onto DpnII fragments of the reference assembly using HiCbox (available at https://github.com/rkoszul/HiC-Box)
Orthologous genes from the six Cotesia species were aligned as described before and codeml (implemented in PAML v4.8) was used to estimate the M0 dN/dS (free ratio model).
The C. congregata genome was generated by de novo assembly of 454 reads using GS De Novo Assembler from the Newbler software package v2.8 57 .

The species phylogeny was performed on this alignment composed of 1058 orthologous for a length of 611 kb using PhyML program 76 with the HKY85 substitution model, previously determined by jModelTest v2.1 77 and the branch support were measured after 1000 bootstrap iterations.
The pair-end reads from C. congregata ovary and venom gland libraries were mapped on the reference genome using TopHat2 85 with default parameters.

Protein sequences were first aligned with MAFFT v7.017 75 and the maximum-likelihood phylogeny was performed with PhyML 76 using the JTT + G + F substitution model for OR and using HKY80 substitution model for P450 and odv-e66 genes.
69 was used to analyze protein sequences seeking for known protein domains in the different databases available in Interproscan.
First, the transposable element annotation was realized following the REPET pipeline comprising a de novo prediction (TEdenovo) and an annotation using TE libraries (TEannot) 65 .
The correspondence between the genes, the localizations on the scaffold and the figures were realized thanks to a custom R script (R Core Team 2013).

The different synteny analyses were performed on the orthologous genes identified by OrthoFinder v1.14 74 and by reciprocal blastp from BLAST + v2.2.28 on the annotated proteins (e-value below 10e -20 ).
The automated gene prediction and annotation of C. congregata genome was done using Gmove (https://github.com/institut-degenomique/Gmove)
Universal single-copy ortholog genes from BUSCO v3 64 were extracted for the six Cotesia species and the four outgroups, aligned using MAFFT v7.017 75 and concatenated.

The different synteny analyses were performed on the orthologous genes identified by OrthoFinder v1.14 74 and by reciprocal blastp from BLAST + v2.2.28 on the annotated proteins (e-value below 10e -20 ).
To analyze gene expression, the raw fragment counts of ovaries and venom glands samples were first converted to counts per million (CPM) using the edgeRimplemented package 87 (R-Core Team 2017).

To determine evolutionary rates within Cotesia genus, single-copy orthologous gene clusters (BUSCO, nudiviral and virulence genes) were first aligned using MACSE 83 to produce reliable codon-based alignments.
First, the transposable element annotation was realized following the REPET pipeline comprising a de novo prediction (TEdenovo) and an annotation using TE libraries (TEannot) 65 .

From these codon alignments, pairwise dN/dS values were estimated between C. congregata and C. sesamiae, the two most diverging species in the Cotesia phylogeny, with PAML v4.8 84 using the YN00 program.

The species phylogeny was performed on this alignment composed of 1058 orthologous for a length of 611 kb using PhyML program 76 with the HKY85 substitution model, previously determined by jModelTest v2.1 77 and the branch support were measured after 1000 bootstrap iterations.

From these codon alignments, pairwise dN/dS values were estimated between C. congregata and C. sesamiae, the two most diverging species in the Cotesia phylogeny, with PAML v4.8 84 using the YN00 program.

Contigs were searched for similarities against the nonredundant NCBI nucleotide (nt) (release November 2019) and the Uniref90 protein (release November 2019) databases using, respectively, blastn from BLAST + v2.7.1 68 and diamond v0.9.29.130 72 .

Orthologous genes between all genes annotated in the six Cotesia species and the four outgroups (Microplitis demolitor, Nasonia vitripennis, Apis mellifera and Drosophila melanogaster) were identified using OrthoFinder v1.14 74 .

Contigs were searched for similarities against the nonredundant NCBI nucleotide (nt) (release November 2019) and the Uniref90 protein (release November 2019) databases using, respectively, blastn from BLAST + v2.7.1 68 and diamond v0.9.29.130 72 .

Reads were then filtered according to different criteria: low-quality bases (Q < 20) at the read extremities, bases after the second N found in a read, read shorter than 30 bp and reads matching with phiX (Illumina intern control) were removed using in-house software (http://www.genoscope.cns. fr/fastxtend) based on the FASTX-Toolkit (http://hannonlab.cshl.edu/fastx_toolkit)
